skill.name: py-fastapi-patterns
skill.description: FastAPI patterns for API design. Use when creating endpoints, handling dependencies, error handling, or working with OpenAPI schemas.
skill.summary: FastAPI patterns for API design. Use when creating endpoints, handling dependencies, error handling,...
skill.author: CJHarmath

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown explanations and Python code examples. No executable scripts, network calls, file system access, or environment variable access. Static findings are false positives triggered by documentation keywords and markdown syntax.

content.value_statement: Building APIs with FastAPI requires understanding dependency injection, response models, and OpenAPI schema design. This skill provides battle-tested patterns that prevent common bugs and improve developer experience for frontend teams.
actual_capabilities: Implement dependency injection with FastAPI Depends
Create proper response models to filter sensitive data
Handle errors with HTTPException and custom handlers
Design clean OpenAPI schemas with descriptions
Organize routes with APIRouter prefixes and tags
Validate request bodies with Pydantic Field validators
limitations: Does not generate complete API projects or boilerplate
Does not integrate with specific databases or ORMs
Does not provide runtime execution or testing capabilities
Focuses on patterns rather than complete implementation examples

use_cases.title: Build Maintainable APIs
use_cases.description: Apply dependency chains and response models to create APIs that are easy to maintain and evolve over time.

use_cases.title: Improve Frontend Integration
use_cases.description: Design OpenAPI schemas that generate accurate TypeScript types for frontend code generation tools.

use_cases.title: Standardize Team Patterns
use_cases.description: Establish consistent error handling and route organization across multiple API services.

prompt_templates.title: Dependency Injection
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a dependency chain in FastAPI for authentication. Include get_session, get_current_user, and get_current_active_user dependencies that can be used in endpoints.

prompt_templates.title: Response Models
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain how to use response_model in FastAPI to prevent exposing internal fields like hashed_password. Show a User model with read and create variants.

prompt_templates.title: Error Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create custom exception handlers in FastAPI that return consistent error responses with error codes? Include both the exception class and the handler.

prompt_templates.title: Route Ordering
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain why route ordering matters in FastAPI. Show an example of how putting /users/me before /users/{user_id} prevents matching issues.

output_examples.input: Create a paginated response model for listing assessments
output: Define a generic PaginatedResponse class with items, total, page, and size fields
FastAPI automatically filters the response to only include AssessmentRead fields
The OpenAPI schema will correctly document the nested structure

output_examples.input: Add CORS middleware to my FastAPI app
output: Add middleware with allow_origins, allow_credentials, allow_methods, and allow_headers
Add CORS middleware early in the middleware stack for proper ordering
Use specific origins instead of wildcard (*) in production

output_examples.input: Create validation for an input field
output: Use Pydantic Field with min_length, max_length, and description parameters
Add a field_validator method to validate against allowed values
Raise ValueError with a clear message for invalid inputs
FastAPI automatically returns 422 status on validation failure

best_practices: Always define specific routes before generic parameterized routes to prevent incorrect matching
Use response_model on every endpoint to control output and generate accurate OpenAPI schemas
Chain dependencies from most generic (session) to most specific (current_user) for reusability
anti_patterns: Omitting response_model exposes internal fields like hashed_password in API responses
Placing generic routes before specific routes causes /users/me to be captured as a user_id parameter
Using bare except clauses or generic HTTPException without status codes creates inconsistent error responses

faq.question: Does this skill work with FastAPI async endpoints?
faq.answer: Yes. All patterns support both sync and async endpoint definitions. Dependencies can be async functions using await.

faq.question: What Python versions are supported?
faq.answer: FastAPI requires Python 3.8 or later. Most patterns work with Python 3.9+ features like the | type union operator.

faq.question: Can I use these patterns with other frameworks?
faq.answer: The dependency injection concept applies to other frameworks. Response models and OpenAPI patterns are FastAPI-specific.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using these patterns?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill contains only documentation patterns. No data leaves your environment when applying these practices.

faq.question: Why am I getting 422 validation errors?
faq.answer: Pydantic v2 is strict by default. Check that your request body matches all Field validators including min_length and max_length constraints.

faq.question: How does this compare to Django REST Framework?
faq.answer: FastAPI provides automatic OpenAPI generation and native async support. DRF has more built-in viewsets but requires more configuration for API docs.
